title: "Imitation of Life" is a thought-provoking drama about race and identity
summary: Sarah and Nora struggle to find their place in the world with regards to their identity. Both women feel that they are betraying their identities when they are forced to pass as something they are not. This film explores the idea that appearances are what matter most in society, and that a personâ€™s social class is the most important thing about them. In the film, George is the son of a rich man, who prefers to keep him in the poorer section of the business so he can remain in control.

content.compiledSource: var d=Object.defineProperty,m=Object.defineProperties;var p=Object.getOwnPropertyDescriptors;var i=Object.getOwnPropertySymbols;var n=Object.prototype.hasOwnProperty,o=Object.prototype.propertyIsEnumerable;var r=(e,a,t)=>a in e?d(e,a,{enumerable:!0,configurable:!0,writable:!0,value:t}):e[a]=t,h=(e,a)=>{for(var t in a||(a={}))n.call(a,t)&&r(e,t,a[t]);if(i)for(var t of i(a))o.call(a,t)&&r(e,t,a[t]);return e},l=(e,a)=>m(e,p(a));var c=(e,a)=>{var t={};for(var s in e)n.call(e,s)&&a.indexOf(s)<0&&(t[s]=e[s]);if(e!=null&&i)for(var s of i(e))a.indexOf(s)<0&&o.call(e,s)&&(t[s]=e[s]);return t};const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent(t){var s=t,{components:e}=s,a=c(s,["components"]);return mdx(MDXLayout,l(h(h({},layoutProps),a),{components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"}),mdx("h2",null,"The Importance of Identity"),mdx("p",null,"Throughout the film, Sarah and Nora struggle to find their place in the world with regards to their identity. Sarah\u2019s light skin means she can pass as white but her brother cannot. Meanwhile, Nora\u2019s dark skin means she can pass as black but her daughter cannot. As a child, Sarah is repeatedly told that because she is light-skinned, she is special and not like the other \u2018darkies\u2019. Yet when she grows up, her skin colour is a barrier to her happiness and she has to pass as white to find a suitable husband. Meanwhile, Nora is also told that she is special because she is dark-skinned, yet she is poor and cannot marry the man she loves. Both women feel that they are somehow betraying their identities when they are forced to pass as something they are not. "),mdx("h2",null,"Passing and Authenticity"),mdx("p",null,"When Nora\u2019s son asks her if she is \u201Cas black as ","[she]"," can be\u201D, she replies, \u201CI\u2019m as black as I can afford to be!\u201D This line expresses both the idea that to be as authentic as possible is to be genuine, yet it also references the fact that we all make choices about what level of \u2018authenticity\u2019 we present ourselves with. When Nora and George pass for white, they are not being authentic to themselves; they are choosing to present themselves as something they are not. When George tells his wife he would \u201Crather be dead\u201D than go back to Africa, he is being less authentic than Nora who has no problem returning home. Yet the two are punished for their choices with tragic consequences. "),mdx("h2",null,"Cultural Framing of Race"),mdx("p",null,"This film critiques the idea that some races are naturally better than others. It is a common idea that leads to much of the discrimination and racism that exists in society. It is explored through the relationship between Sarah\u2019s boyfriend Harry and her mother Nora. Harry is passionate about jazz and wants to be a professional singer, while Nora works as a waitress and is unimpressed by his \u201Cnoisy music\u201D. Nora refuses to see Harry as an equal, despite the fact that he is a hard-working, intelligent man who shares many of her interests. She refuses to acknowledge that he has the right to pursue his passions, and feels that he is less of a person because of his \u2018lower-class\u2019 status. While she does change her mind about Harry and recognises his worth later in the story, this scene offers insight into the ways cultural prejudice can affect our relationships. "),mdx("h2",null,"Classism"),mdx("p",null,"Classism is the privileging of one segment of society over another based on their financial status. In the film, George is the son of a rich man, who prefers to keep him in the poorer section of the business so he can remain in control. When George and Nora fall in love, she cannot be with him because of his social class. Later, when George has changed his appearance and is posing as a white man, he is able to be with Vida, a rich woman who is his new employer\u2019s daughter. This film explores the idea that appearances are what matter most in society, and that a person\u2019s social class is the most important thing about them. "),mdx("h2",null,"Pansexuality?"),mdx("p",null,"During the film, George often comments that he \u201Cthinks like a woman\u201D. He is shown to have a remarkably empathetic nature that likely has something to do with his decision to marry Vida and pass as white. He recognizes that her desire to marry a white man stems from a desire to be admired and validated by everyone around her. Yet he is also shown to be a devoted father and husband and genuinely in love with Vida. George is also impulsive and temperamental, making impulsive decisions that do not always work out for the best. Despite this, he is given the label of \u2018woman\u2019, suggesting that he is not a man to be taken seriously because of his emotional tendencies. "),mdx("h2",null,"Conclusion"),mdx("p",null,"Released in the year of cinema\u2019s first black Best Actor winner, this film is a thought-provoking melodrama about passing as a marker of authenticity. Rather than any superficial discussion of how many different kinds of people there are or whether one kind is better than another, it is an examination of what it means to be an individual in society by exploring the challenges that arise when one appears to be something they are not. "),mdx("p",null,"This film offers commentary on racial identity, classism and even pansexuality through these characters, providing insight into their experiences and highlighting inequality wherever it exists."))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

"Whiplash" Is a Tense and Exhilarating Look at the World of Jazz

"Mad Max: Fury Road" Is a Post-Apocalyptic Joyride

intro.compiledSource:
var d=Object.defineProperty,c=Object.defineProperties;var g=Object.getOwnPropertyDescriptors;var r=Object.getOwnPropertySymbols;var n=Object.prototype.hasOwnProperty,s=Object.prototype.propertyIsEnumerable;var h=(e,t,a)=>t in e?d(e,t,{enumerable:!0,configurable:!0,writable:!0,value:a}):e[t]=a,i=(e,t)=>{for(var a in t||(t={}))n.call(t,a)&&h(e,a,t[a]);if(r)for(var a of r(t))s.call(t,a)&&h(e,a,t[a]);return e},l=(e,t)=>c(e,g(t));var u=(e,t)=>{var a={};for(var o in e)n.call(e,o)&&t.indexOf(o)<0&&(a[o]=e[o]);if(e!=null&&r)for(var o of r(e))t.indexOf(o)<0&&s.call(e,o)&&(a[o]=e[o]);return a};const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent(a){var o=a,{components:e}=o,t=u(o,["components"]);return mdx(MDXLayout,l(i(i({},layoutProps),t),{components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"}),mdx("p",null,`For some, the world will end in fire. For others, it will end in ice. And for others still, it will just fizzle out like a can of cheap fuel on an old race car. But no matter how you look at it, the apocalypse is coming. The only question is when?
This was the sentiment that drove much of popular culture throughout the 70s and 80s. Films like \u201CMad Max\u201D and \u201CThe Road Warrior\u201D were cautionary tales about the future of mankind brought on by a series of devastating natural and man-made disasters; "Mad Max" being set during a prolonged drought, and "The Road Warrior" taking place after a catastrophic failure of an oil refinery leads to widespread pollution and destruction as well as a shortage of gasoline (which is what inspired the term \u201CRoad Warrior\u201D).
In these movies, there are also factions that have arisen to take advantage of these new conditions: In "Mad Max", we see gangs whose primary function is to steal fuel from other scavenger tribes; In "The Road Warrior", we see roving bands that are essentially highwaymen that prey upon small towns using their road-warrior combat skillset; And in both movies we see heroes who fight against evil not because they want to be evil but because they are good people trying to save those they love in terrible times.
These subtexts have been explored time and time again throughout history through literature such as The Bible`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: "The Big Short" Is a Searing Indictment of the Financial Industry

intro.compiledSource:
var d=Object.defineProperty,c=Object.defineProperties;var g=Object.getOwnPropertyDescriptors;var s=Object.getOwnPropertySymbols;var i=Object.prototype.hasOwnProperty,a=Object.prototype.propertyIsEnumerable;var h=(e,t,o)=>t in e?d(e,t,{enumerable:!0,configurable:!0,writable:!0,value:o}):e[t]=o,r=(e,t)=>{for(var o in t||(t={}))i.call(t,o)&&h(e,o,t[o]);if(s)for(var o of s(t))a.call(t,o)&&h(e,o,t[o]);return e},u=(e,t)=>c(e,g(t));var l=(e,t)=>{var o={};for(var n in e)i.call(e,n)&&t.indexOf(n)<0&&(o[n]=e[n]);if(e!=null&&s)for(var n of s(e))t.indexOf(n)<0&&a.call(e,n)&&(o[n]=e[n]);return o};const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent(o){var n=o,{components:e}=n,t=l(n,["components"]);return mdx(MDXLayout,u(r(r({},layoutProps),t),{components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"}),mdx("p",null,`The film version of The Big Short hits theaters this Friday, and it\u2019s not subtle. Its tagline is \u201CThere\u2019s a sucker born every minute. But they don\u2019t grow up thinking they can be con men. They get taught to be one.\u201D And its trailer goes on to say, \u201CThe housing bubble was about to burst\u2026 And a group of misfits saw it coming. Now these unlikely heroes must band together and bring down the greedy villains who crashed the world economy\u2026 Before anyone else gets hurt.\u201D
Unfortunately, that last part is not hyperbole. The actions of unscrupulous financial engineers \u2014 colloquially known as \u201Cbankers\u201D \u2014 led directly to the Great Recession in 2008, which cost millions their jobs and homes, while triggering widespread deflation and anemic growth throughout much of the developed world for years thereafter.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: "The Imitation Game" Is a Fascinating Look at the Life of Alan Turing

var m=Object.defineProperty,l=Object.defineProperties;var u=Object.getOwnPropertyDescriptors;var r=Object.getOwnPropertySymbols;var s=Object.prototype.hasOwnProperty,i=Object.prototype.propertyIsEnumerable;var c=(e,t,n)=>t in e?m(e,t,{enumerable:!0,configurable:!0,writable:!0,value:n}):e[t]=n,o=(e,t)=>{for(var n in t||(t={}))s.call(t,n)&&c(e,n,t[n]);if(r)for(var n of r(t))i.call(t,n)&&c(e,n,t[n]);return e},h=(e,t)=>l(e,u(t));var d=(e,t)=>{var n={};for(var a in e)s.call(e,a)&&t.indexOf(a)<0&&(n[a]=e[a]);if(e!=null&&r)for(var a of r(e))t.indexOf(a)<0&&i.call(e,a)&&(n[a]=e[a]);return n};const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent(n){var a=n,{components:e}=a,t=d(a,["components"]);return mdx(MDXLayout,h(o(o({},layoutProps),t),{components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"}),mdx("p",null,`In 1937, Alan Turing was born in Northern England. He would go on to become a war hero, pioneer of computer science, and one of the greatest minds of the 20th century. In 1951, he was convicted of \u201Cgross indecency\u201D and chemically castrated as punishment. Two years later, he killed himself with cyanide. This is his story.
Turing was a brilliant man with many interests that went beyond mathematics and computer science: chess, cryptography, music theory and programming computers to sing are just some examples. This diverse background helped him crack the Nazi Enigma code during World War II at Bletchley Park (which has been nicknamed "Codebreaking Castle"). This saved countless lives and accelerated the end of the war by two years. After the war ended in 1945, Turing continued working as an cryptanalyst for a few more years before turning his attention to other interests \u2013- and it is these interests that led to his arrest and untimely death at age 41.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: Chvrches' 'Love Is Dead' Is a Pop Gem

But there are still some great pop albums that aren\u2019t filled with auto-tune and EDM drops.On May 25th, the Scottish band Chvrches released their third album called \u201C Love is Dead.\u201D The synth-pop band has lots of happy vibes and catchy hooks on their new album. It\u2019s a pleasant listen but might not be what you expect if you only know them from their first two albums. The band took a left turn creatively, covering topics like technology, isolation and death rather than dancing around in your bedroom to this record.
Chvrses has gained more popularity among a different group of fans by releasing this album than they ever did with their first two releases combined. This is partially because they have expanded their audience by collaborating on songs with Haim and Bleachers recently as well as making this change in sound so now they have crossover appeal to radio listeners too!`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: "The Theory of Everything" Is a Touching Biopic of Stephen Hawking
"The Martian" Is a Triumph of Science Fiction

intro.compiledSource:
var l=Object.defineProperty,m=Object.defineProperties;var c=Object.getOwnPropertyDescriptors;var n=Object.getOwnPropertySymbols;var s=Object.prototype.hasOwnProperty,r=Object.prototype.propertyIsEnumerable;var h=(e,t,o)=>t in e?l(e,t,{enumerable:!0,configurable:!0,writable:!0,value:o}):e[t]=o,i=(e,t)=>{for(var o in t||(t={}))s.call(t,o)&&h(e,o,t[o]);if(n)for(var o of n(t))r.call(t,o)&&h(e,o,t[o]);return e},d=(e,t)=>m(e,c(t));var u=(e,t)=>{var o={};for(var a in e)s.call(e,a)&&t.indexOf(a)<0&&(o[a]=e[a]);if(e!=null&&n)for(var a of n(e))t.indexOf(a)<0&&r.call(e,a)&&(o[a]=e[a]);return o};const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent(o){var a=o,{components:e}=a,t=u(a,["components"]);return mdx(MDXLayout,d(i(i({},layoutProps),t),{components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"}),mdx("p",null,`Ridley Scott\u2019s new movie, The Martian, is based on a novel of the same name by Andy Weir. It\u2019s about an astronaut called Mark Watney who gets stranded on Mars after his crewmates think he\u2019s dead and leave without him. This might seem as just another case of annoying Hollywood over-simplification: after all, we get so many bioengineered super-geniuses with computer uplink implants that they can become trapped in remote locations via their own stupidity. But there\u2019s more to it than that.
In both book and film, the humanity of Watney comes out in everything he does to survive: logical thinking (how can I eat this potato again?), ingenuity (I need water; how do I distill it from our CO2 filters), courage (explore the abandoned outpost), and compassion (contact my family). He also has a lot of fun with his predicament, cracking jokes through his video log and even going disco.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: Charlie Puth's 'Voicenotes' Is a Solid Effort

intro.compiledSource:
var p=Object.defineProperty,c=Object.defineProperties;var d=Object.getOwnPropertyDescriptors;var n=Object.getOwnPropertySymbols;var a=Object.prototype.hasOwnProperty,r=Object.prototype.propertyIsEnumerable;var h=(t,e,o)=>e in t?p(t,e,{enumerable:!0,configurable:!0,writable:!0,value:o}):t[e]=o,i=(t,e)=>{for(var o in e||(e={}))a.call(e,o)&&h(t,o,e[o]);if(n)for(var o of n(e))r.call(e,o)&&h(t,o,e[o]);return t},l=(t,e)=>c(t,d(e));var u=(t,e)=>{var o={};for(var s in t)a.call(t,s)&&e.indexOf(s)<0&&(o[s]=t[s]);if(t!=null&&n)for(var s of n(t))e.indexOf(s)<0&&r.call(t,s)&&(o[s]=t[s]);return o};const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent(o){var s=o,{components:t}=s,e=u(s,["components"]);return mdx(MDXLayout,l(i(i({},layoutProps),e),{components:t,mdxType:"MDXLayout"}),mdx("p",null,`Charlie Puth has been on a roll lately, with three top 40 hits in the last two years. He\u2019s also worked with some pretty big names (including one we\u2019ll get to shortly). Now, he\u2019s back with another new album, titled \u201CVoicenotes.\u201D It\u2019s a solid effort that shows growth and maturity, as well as keeping Puth\u2019s fun and lighthearted style.
At its core, Voicenotes is an acoustic pop album. However, it goes deeper than just putting electric guitars aside; these songs are stripped right down to the bare bones. There\u2019s still plenty of production value\u2014especially on the third track\u2014but it feels like Puth made a conscious decision not to hide behind anything.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;
